title: High school football roundup
text:
4 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
CARDINGTON - Cardington-Lincoln kept its hopes for a playoff berth and at least a share of the Mid Ohio Athletic Conference Blue Division title alive with a 31-24 overtime win over Highland Friday night. 
Cardington-Lincoln is now 7-2 overall and tied atop the Blue Division with Highland and Fredericktown at 5-1. 
The Pirates host Fredericktown Friday, and a win would give them at least a piece of the division crown. 
Highland (5-4 overall) had its five-game winning streak snapped, and the Scots were mathematically eliminated from the playoff race with the loss. 
Highland can clinch a tie for the division championship Friday if it beats Mount Gilead. It would then share the title with the winner of the Cardington-Fredericktown game. 
Wide receiver Daniel Kill threw a 20-yard pass for a touchdown to Devin Pearl in overtime to seal the win over Highland for the Pirates. 
Cardington had rallied from a 21-14 third-quarter deficit to take a lead late in regulation. 
Luke McCarrell passed 50 yards to Pearl for a score and Brandon Steckel kicked a 30-yard field goal to hand Cardington a 24-21 lead with 38 seconds left in regulation. 
Highland used those final seconds wisely to move the ball deep into Pirate territory. On the last play of regulation, Satchel Denton kicked a 30-yard field goal for Highland to send the game into extra time tied at 24. 
Cardington jumped out in front 7-0 as Trey Williams passed 30 yards to Kill for a TD. 
Highland tied the game at 7 when Max Schreiber passed 89 yards to Dakota Bunting for a touchdown. 
The teams traded scores as Scott Osborne ran 28 yards for a touchdown for Cardington and Andrew Davis hit paydirt from two yards away for Highland. 
Highland took its 21-14 lead on a 43-yard TD run by Bunting. 
Osborne had 110 rushing yards on 12 carries while McCarrell hit 8-of-17 passes for 133 yards. 
Schreiber threw for 243 yards and Bunting ran for 141 yards for the Scots. 
Fredericktown 41, Northmor 3 
Fredericktown set up its big game with Cardington-Lincoln by stopping Northmor in the MOAC. 
Brenden Reed ran for four TDs as the Freddies improved to 7-2 overall. Reed hit the end zone on efforts of 14, 8, 35 and 9 yards as the Freddies moved out on top 28-0. 
After Jake Farley hit a 24-yard field goal for Northmor (1-5, 2-7), Dillion Smith passed for four yards to Jake Streby for a TD and ran 25 yards for another score. 
Fredericktown held a 485-143 edge in total yards in the game. 
Reed accounted for 221 rushing yards on 24 carries for Fredericktown while Smith ran for 109 yards and threw for another 143. Braxton McQueen caught five passes for 82 yards for Fredericktown. 
Jordan Wiseman tossed for 109 yards to lead the Golden Knights’ offense. Frank Keller brought in five balls for 46 yards. 
Galion 62, North Union 21 
Galion put a huge dent in North Union’s playoff chances while enhancing its own with an MOAC victory. 
North Union (2-4 MOAC) is still alive in the playoff race with a 4-5 record, but just barely. The Wildcats would have to beat Buckeye Valley Friday and get a lot of help to qualify. 
Chase Cooke hit 10-of-12 passes for 289 yards and one TD for Galion (4-2, 7-2) while Drake Barnett ran for 144 yards and four scores. Jacob Fryer tallied three TDs for the Tigers, two coming via the rush, and Caleb Ivy added a touchdown run. 
Galion had a 42-0 lead before North Union cracked the scoreboard. 
Luke Krawczyk tallied touchdowns for the Wildcats on runs of 22 and 13 yards. Nate Hammons scored a TD on a 13-yard run. 
Krawczyk led NU in rushing with 116 yards on 16 carries while Hammons posted 62 yards on 10 trips. 
Centerburg 63, Mount Gilead 37 
Centerburg kept its faint playoff hopes alive with an MOAC win over Mount Gilead. 
The loss eliminated Mount Gilead (3-3, 4-5) from playoff consideration. 
The teams combined for 960 yards of offense as Centerburg improved to 4-2 in the conference and to 5-4 overall. 
Gunnar Gregory passed for 320 yards and five TDs for the Trojans. He completed 23-of-39 passes. 
Jacob Rings ran for four scores and 165 yards for the winners while Kyle Hogan caught nine passes for 165 yards and three touchdowns. Sterling Armstrong and Braxton Mead each caught a TD pass for the winners. 
Centerburg scored 34 points in the first half but led by only 11 at 34-23 by the intermission. The Trojans were on top 49-31 following three periods. 
Deondre Cook rushed for 196 yards for the Indians while Anthony Clark and Jonah Barnett each tallied 104 yards on the ground. Cook threw a touchdown pass to Tyler Bland and ran for a pair of scores while Barnett had two TD runs. 
Chris Schmitt led Centerburg’s defense with 11 tackles, 10 of which were solo. 
Other games 
In other MOAC games Friday, East Knox (1-5, 1-8) defeated Elgin (0-6, 2-7) 7-0 while Pleasant (1-5, 3-6) outscored Fairbanks (0-6, 0-9) 68-31. No further information was available on those games. 4 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://ohne.ws/1LU84uZ MORE STORIES
